title: How to Freeze Pancakes

steps.headline: Cook pancakes according to your chosen recipe.
steps.description: Just about any type of pancake will freeze well, so cook your pancakes however you like. Adding tasty extras like fruit, nuts, or chocolate chips to the batter won’t prevent your pancakes from freezing properly. However, take care not to add any toppings, such as butter or syrup, until you are ready to eat the pancakes.

steps.headline: Place some parchment paper on a baking sheet.
steps.description: If you don’t have parchment paper, you can use some other type of non-stick liner, such as a silicone baking mat or non-stick aluminum foil. This will prevent your pancakes from adhering to the baking sheet when they freeze.

steps.headline: Arrange the pancakes on the baking sheet in a single layer.
steps.description: Carefully transfer the pancakes onto the baking sheet you have prepared. Make sure not to allow the pancakes to overlap or touch each other on the sheet, although you don’t need to leave a lot of space between them. If you have a lot of pancakes to freeze, you can place another sheet of parchment paper on top of your first layer of pancakes, and add a second layer of pancakes on top of that.

steps.headline: Let the pancakes cool.
steps.description: Once the pancakes are on the baking sheet, let them sit uncovered at room temperature for a few minutes to cool off. Gently touch one of the pancakes to see if it is completely cool to the touch. Putting pancakes in the freezer while they are still hot will not only slow down the freezing process, but it could also warm up other foods in your freezer and cause them to defrost a little.

steps.headline: Put the pancakes in your freezer for 30 minutes to 1 hour.
steps.description: Place the entire baking sheet in your freezer with the pancakes on it. Let the pancakes sit in the freezer until they are frozen solid. This should take about half an hour to 1 hour. If your pancakes are still not fully frozen after an hour, give them a little more time (e.g., around 20 minutes) and check again. Keep checking until they feel solid to the touch.

parts.name: Storing Your Frozen Pancakes in the Freezer

steps.headline: Transfer the pancakes to a freezer-safe container.
steps.description: Once your pancakes are completely frozen, stack them up and move them from the baking sheet into a sealed container for storage. You can also use zip-top freezer bags.

steps.headline: Put wax or parchment paper between each pancake to prevent sticking.
steps.description: If your pancakes are thoroughly frozen before you store them, they shouldn’t stick together. If you’re worried about sticking, however, you can separate each pancake with a piece of non-stick wax or parchment paper.

steps.headline: Store your frozen pancakes for up to 2 months.
steps.description: If your frozen pancakes are kept in a well-sealed container or bag, they should stay fresh for several weeks. You may wish to label your container with the date so that you know how long to keep them. Whenever you’re ready, you can reheat your pancakes in a microwave, toaster, or conventional oven.

text: Freezing before Storing Cook pancakes according to your chosen recipe. Just about any type of pancake will freeze well, so cook your pancakes however you like. Adding tasty extras like fruit, nuts, or chocolate chips to the batter won’t prevent your pancakes from freezing properly. However, take care not to add any toppings, such as butter or syrup, until you are ready to eat the pancakes. Place some parchment paper on a baking sheet. If you don’t have parchment paper, you can use some other type of non-stick liner, such as a silicone baking mat or non-stick aluminum foil. This will prevent your pancakes from adhering to the baking sheet when they freeze. Arrange the pancakes on the baking sheet in a single layer. Carefully transfer the pancakes onto the baking sheet you have prepared. Make sure not to allow the pancakes to overlap or touch each other on the sheet, although you don’t need to leave a lot of space between them. If you have a lot of pancakes to freeze, you can place another sheet of parchment paper on top of your first layer of pancakes, and add a second layer of pancakes on top of that. Let the pancakes cool. Once the pancakes are on the baking sheet, let them sit uncovered at room temperature for a few minutes to cool off. Gently touch one of the pancakes to see if it is completely cool to the touch. Putting pancakes in the freezer while they are still hot will not only slow down the freezing process, but it could also warm up other foods in your freezer and cause them to defrost a little. Put the pancakes in your freezer for 30 minutes to 1 hour. Place the entire baking sheet in your freezer with the pancakes on it. Let the pancakes sit in the freezer until they are frozen solid. This should take about half an hour to 1 hour. If your pancakes are still not fully frozen after an hour, give them a little more time (e.g., around 20 minutes) and check again. Keep checking until they feel solid to the touch. Storing Your Frozen Pancakes in the Freezer Transfer the pancakes to a freezer-safe container. Once your pancakes are completely frozen, stack them up and move them from the baking sheet into a sealed container for storage. You can also use zip-top freezer bags. Put wax or parchment paper between each pancake to prevent sticking. If your pancakes are thoroughly frozen before you store them, they shouldn’t stick together. If you’re worried about sticking, however, you can separate each pancake with a piece of non-stick wax or parchment paper. Store your frozen pancakes for up to 2 months. If your frozen pancakes are kept in a well-sealed container or bag, they should stay fresh for several weeks. You may wish to label your container with the date so that you know how long to keep them. Whenever you’re ready, you can reheat your pancakes in a microwave, toaster, or conventional oven.
